text: And Abram was fourscore  and six years old, when Hagar bare Ishmael to Abram.
text_kjv: And Abram was fourscore  and six years old, when Hagar bare Ishmael to Abram.
text_niv: Abram was eighty-six years old when Hagar bore him Ishmael.
text_esv: Abram was eighty-six years old when Hagar bore Ishmael to Abram.
text_nlt: Abram was eighty-six years old when Ishmael was born.
text_msg: Abram was eighty-six years old when Hagar gave him his son, Ishmael.
text_nasb: Abram was eighty-six years old when Hagar bore Ishmael to him.
context: Genesis 16:16 serves as a chronological marker, anchoring the events within the broader narrative of Abram's life and God's covenant with him. In ancient Near Eastern societies, barrenness was a significant source of shame and social stigma for women. A wife's primary role was to bear children, particularly sons, to continue the family lineage and inherit property. Abram and Sarai's inability to conceive after many years would have been a profound source of anxiety and societal pressure. The practice of a man having children through a maidservant was not uncommon, though it was not the ideal situation. This practice, while providing an heir, often led to complex family dynamics and potential conflicts. Understanding this cultural context illuminates Sarai's desperation and Abram's willingness to consider an alternative method of fulfilling God's promise of numerous descendants. The specific age provided, 86, is significant because it emphasizes the length of time Abram and Sarai had been waiting for God's promise to be fulfilled, which was about ten years after arriving in Canaan (Genesis 12:4). The mention of Hagar's name is also crucial, highlighting the human element and agency involved in this episode, a story of faith mixed with impatience and culturally acceptable (though eventually problematic) solutions.
meaning: Genesis 16:16, though seemingly a simple statement of fact, carries profound theological weight. It underscores the tension between God's promise and human impatience. God had promised Abram numerous descendants, but after years of waiting, Abram and Sarai took matters into their own hands, leading to the birth of Ishmael through Hagar. This act reveals a lack of complete trust in God's timing and method. While God's promise was ultimately fulfilled through Isaac, the line of Ishmael would become a separate nation and a source of conflict (Genesis 16:12). Ishmael's birth is not explicitly condemned, suggesting God's sovereignty even in human failure, but it highlights the consequences of acting outside of God's will. The verse can also be interpreted as a testament to God's patience. Despite Abram and Sarai's flawed actions, God remained faithful to His covenant, continuing to work towards the fulfillment of His promise. The inclusion of Hagar, an Egyptian slave, is also significant. It demonstrates that God's story is not limited to the chosen people; it encompasses individuals from all backgrounds. Ishmael's very existence serves as a reminder that God's grace extends even to those who are not directly part of the covenant line. Ultimately, this verse highlights the need for unwavering faith in God's promises, even when circumstances seem impossible.
application: The brief but potent statement in Genesis 16:16 holds several applications for modern believers. Firstly, it serves as a crucial reminder to trust God's timing. We often become impatient when facing delays in the fulfillment of our prayers or desires. Like Abram and Sarai, we may be tempted to take matters into our own hands, seeking our own solutions instead of patiently waiting for God's provision. This verse challenges us to resist the urge to manipulate circumstances or force outcomes. Secondly, the story surrounding this verse teaches us about the consequences of our choices. While God can redeem even our mistakes, our actions often have unintended repercussions. Abram and Sarai's decision to have a child through Hagar led to conflict within their household and ultimately resulted in Ishmael's descendants becoming a separate nation with a complex relationship with Israel. This reminds us to consider the potential ramifications of our decisions and to seek God's guidance before acting. Thirdly, this verse encourages us to recognize God's sovereignty even in our failures. God remained faithful to Abram despite his imperfections. Similarly, God's grace extends to us even when we stumble and make mistakes. We should not despair when we fall short, but instead, turn to God in repentance and trust in His forgiveness. Fourthly, we need to be sensitive to the needs of others, even those who seem different from us. Hagar was a vulnerable slave girl, and Abram and Sarai's actions significantly impacted her life. This reminds us to treat all people with dignity and compassion, regardless of their background or social status.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we confess that we often struggle with impatience and doubt. Like Abram and Sarai, we are tempted to take matters into our own hands when we don't see immediate answers to our prayers. Forgive us for our lack of faith and help us to trust in Your perfect timing. Grant us the wisdom to discern Your will and the courage to wait patiently for Your provision. Lord, help us to remember that Your promises are always true, even when circumstances seem impossible. Teach us to learn from the mistakes of those who have gone before us, and to seek Your guidance in all that we do. May we be mindful of the impact our choices have on others, and strive to treat all people with love and compassion. Strengthen our faith and increase our trust in You. In Jesus' name, we pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: Specifying Abram's age emphasizes the length of time he had been waiting for God's promised heir. It highlights his and Sarai's advanced age, making the eventual birth of Isaac seem even more miraculous and demonstrating God's power to fulfill His promises beyond human limitations.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: Why does the Bible specify Abram's age at Ishmael's birth?

faqs.answer: The Bible doesn't explicitly call Ishmael's birth a 'sin', but it's presented as a result of Abram and Sarai's lack of complete faith in God's timing and method. It was a human solution to a divine problem, which led to future conflicts and tensions.
faqs.question: Q2: Is Ishmael's birth a 'sin' in the biblical narrative?

faqs.answer: Despite Abram's flawed actions, God remained faithful to His promise. He didn't abandon Abram but continued to work towards the fulfillment of His covenant, even using the situation to bring about other nations and blessings.
faqs.question: Q3: What does this verse tell us about God's faithfulness?

faqs.answer: Hagar's story is intertwined with this verse. She was used as a means to an end by Sarai and Abram. Her vulnerability and subsequent experiences highlight the complex social and emotional issues arising from this unconventional family arrangement.
faqs.question: Q4: How does Hagar's story relate to this verse?

faqs.answer: Ishmael represents a path chosen out of impatience and a human solution. Isaac, on the other hand, is the son of promise, born through miraculous intervention, demonstrating God's power and faithfulness to His covenant.
